metadata.title: Loan-to-Cost (LTC) Ratio Calculator
metadata.description: Calculate Loan-to-Cost (LTC) for real estate and development financing using either a direct total-project-cost input or an itemized cost breakdown. Includes validation notes, accuracy caveats, and references to relevant standards.

from_total.label: From total project cost
from_total.description: Calculate LTC using a single total project cost value.

from_components.label: From itemized cost breakdown
from_components.description: Calculate LTC by summing purchase and hard/soft costs to derive total project cost.

total_components.expression: purchase_price + construction_costs + renovation_costs + soft_costs + contingency + other_costs
total_components.label: Total project cost (components)

introduction: Loan-to-Cost (LTC) is the ratio of the loan amount to the total project cost and is commonly used by lenders and developers to assess financing risk during acquisition, construction, or renovation projects.

This calculator supports two workflow modes: enter a single verified total project cost, or provide an itemized cost breakdown that the tool will sum to derive the total. Use the method that best matches your underwriting documents.
methodology: LTC is computed as loan_amount divided by total_project_cost. Total project cost may be entered directly or derived by summing cost line items.
When using itemized inputs, the calculator sums purchase, construction, renovation, soft costs, contingency, and other costs to form the project total before computing LTC.

Values must be provided in the same currency and reflect lender-accepted bases (hard and soft costs as defined in your loan documents). Results are displayed as a percentage and rounded for presentation.
how_is_calculated: Step 1: Determine loan_amount (the principal amount requested or approved).
Step 2a (Total mode): Use total_project_cost as provided.
Step 2b (Components mode): Sum purchase_price + construction_costs + renovation_costs + soft_costs + contingency + other_costs to get total_project_cost.
Step 3: LTC = loan_amount / total_project_cost. Displayed as a percentage.
examples: Example 1: Loan amount $1,000,000; total project cost $2,500,000 → LTC = 1,000,000 / 2,500,000 = 40%.
Example 2: Loan amount $4,000,000; itemized costs sum to $5,000,000 → LTC = 4,000,000 / 5,000,000 = 80%.

faqs.question: What does LTC tell a lender?
faqs.answer: LTC indicates the portion of project cost financed by debt. Higher LTC means greater lender exposure and may require additional equity, guarantees, or higher interest rates.

faqs.question: How is LTC different from Loan-to-Value (LTV)?
faqs.answer: LTC compares loan to project cost, while LTV compares loan to the appraised value of the collateral. Both metrics are used together in underwriting but measure different risk vectors.

faqs.question: What if total project cost is zero or missing?
faqs.answer: Division by zero is invalid. The calculator will not produce an LTC result if total project cost is zero or omitted. Ensure the total project cost is entered or itemized inputs sum to a positive number.

faqs.question: Are contingency and soft costs included?
faqs.answer: Yes. When using the itemized mode, include contingency and soft costs if they are part of the lender-approved project budget. Exclude costs not accepted by your lender.

faqs.question: How precise are results?
faqs.answer: Displayed results are rounded for clarity. Precision depends on input accuracy. For legal or regulatory filings, preserve full precision from source calculations and verify against lender documentation.

glossary.definition: A ratio equal to loan amount divided by the total project cost, expressed as a percentage.
The sum of all costs required to complete the project, including purchase, construction, soft costs, contingency, and any other lender-allowed expenses.
Direct construction costs such as materials and labor.
Indirect project costs such as design, permits, fees, and financing costs.
